column4: Im an ubuntu n00b.  everytime i have someone in my group create a folder or copy files-- the permissions are always for that user and not the whole group!  I've configured the group too have the permissions i wanted too.
can  anyone tell me how to do this permissions thing? right now they've copied something to a web server but the permissions are-rw-r-r-- which is no good
can anyone help my permissions issue?
how are your files being uploaded to the server?
ftp mostly.
but sometimes i just copy them over in explorer...
you'll need to configure the umask directive in your ftpd's config file
also check the umask of the directory you are uploading to (on the server)
if vsftpd is what you use

well, if you want permissions preserved in their entirety -- umask ought to be 000 - but be warned, this is severely insecure -- anyone could upload something dangerous and have the chance to execute it
the default umask is secure - i suggest you keep it unless you have a real specific need to change it, and if you do change it, make sure you secure your machine up properly
but the files that are being ftp'd can't even be read over http due to the permissions..  its 022 right now

not ftp access, they'll need some kind of shell or script running (e.g. those running on webservers) -- but, if vsftpd ever has an exploit and people can invoke a shell through it, you have a big problem
what should ftp umask be, generally?
I think you need to configure permissions via ownership on that directory -- make sure that the www-data group has ability to read on that directory
if you have apache - then you should have that group -- verify with.  grep -i www /etc/group
right, so you need to have the www-data get read permissions on the directory in question
you can only give users and groups permissions to read/write/execute -- not files and directories themselves

so this i think bering me back to square one.  My group has the proper permissions.  which i thought meant all user in that group would have those permissions when uploading/moving/creating.. but this is not the case as i cannot delete anything by a user in my own group.
which group owns that directory? ;)  i'm hinting at something here
the group that owns that directory (www) is root
